questions.text: A software engineer presents to the outpatient department with easy fatiguability. He gives a history of sitting in front of the computer for 12-14 hours. He consumes a lot of junk food with very few fruits and vegetables. Hb is 9 g/dl, and MCV is 80 fl. What is the most likely cause of this patient’s anemia?
questions.explanation:
Microcytic Anaemia

Normocytic Anaemia

Macrocytic Anaemia
  • Sideroblastic anemia.
  • Iron deficiency anaemia.
  • Thalassemia.
  • Anemia of chronic disease.
  • Lead poisoning.

 

(Mnemonic- SITAL)
  • Acute Blood Loss
  • Hemolytic Anaemia(hereditary spherocytosis)
  • Anemia of Chronic Disease
  • Bone Marrow Disorders (e.g., Aplastic Anaemia)
  • Renal Disease
  • Endocrine Disorders (e.g., Hypothyroidism)
  • Early stages of iron deficiency anaemia.
  • Vitamin B12 Deficiency
  • Folate Deficiency
  • Alcohol Abuse
  • Liver Disease
  • Hypothyroidism
  • Myelodysplastic Syndrome

questions.text: A patient is diagnosed with B-cell leukaemia. Which of the following are poor prognostic factors? Hyperdiploidy Age <1 year t(9:22) t(4:11)
questions.explanation:
Favorable Prognostic factors

Unfavorable prognostic factors

  • Age: 1-10 years
  • Leucocyte count < 50000/µl
  • Hyperploidy
  • t (12:21)
  • L1 ALL
  • Response to treatment
  • Early Pre B-cell ALL
  • Female
  • Extreme age group: <1 year or >10 years
  • Hypoploidy
  • t(9:22) and t(4:11)
  • L2 and L3 ALL and mature B cell ALL
  • Total leukocyte count >50,000/cubic.mm
  • Black males
  • Organomegaly
  • CNS Leukemia
  • Absence of CD10
  • Remission> 14 days

A 24-year-old male patient presents with anaemia. Both his father and paternal aunt experienced similar illnesses and were effectively treated with splenectomy. The patient's peripheral blood smear resembles the one depicted in the accompanying illustration, showing spherocytes. What other abnormalities can be anticipated?
Which of the following is not likely to be seen in a patient with paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH)?
A 45-year-old male patient was diagnosed with iron deficiency anaemia. Which of the following is true about the intracellular regulation of iron in the above condition?

questions.text: All of the following are associated with massive splenomegaly, except:
questions.explanation:
Aplastic Anemia

It refers to a syndrome of chronic primary hematopoietic failure and attendant pancytopenia.

Cause 

Acquired

  • Idiopathic
  • Acquired stem cell defects
  • Immune-mediated

Chemical agents

  • Dose-related (Alkylating agents, antimetabolites, benzene, chloramphenicol, inorganic arsenicals)
  • Idiosyncratic (Chloramphenicol, phenylbutazone, organic arsenicals, methylphenylethylhydantoin, carbamazepine, penicillamine, gold salts)

Physical agents

  • Whole-body irradiation
  • Viral infections
  • Hepatitis (unknown virus)
  • Cytomegalovirus infections
  • Epstein-Barr virus infections
  • Herpes zoster (varicella zoster)

Inherited

  • Fanconi anemia
  • Telomerase defects

Pathogenesis

The pathogenesis of aplastic anaemia is not fully understood. However, two major etiologies have been invoked:

  • Extrinsic (immune-mediated suppression of marrow progenitors)
  • Intrinsic (abnormality of stem cells)

Clinical features
  • Onset: Insidious.
  • Pancytopenia
  • Anaemia (progressive weakness, pallor, and dyspnea)
  • Thrombocytopenia (petechiae and ecchymoses)
  • Neutropenia (frequent and persistent infections or the sudden onset of chills, fever, and prostration).
  • Splenomegaly is absent (Option B)
  • The red cells are usually slightly macrocytic and normochromic.

Microscopy
  • Hypocellular bone marrow is largely devoid of hematopoietic cells; often, only fat cells, fibrous stroma, and scattered lymphocytes and plasma cells remain.
  • Marrow aspirates often yield little material (a “dry tap”).

questions.text: A child presented with bilateral proptosis. From the peripheral smear, he was suspected to have chloroma. What is the next investigation of choice?

Which of the following statements regarding the effect of glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase deficiency is correct? Decrease in reduced glutathione Decrease NADPH Decreased lipid peroxidation Decreased RBC membrane damage
Which of the following is used in treating sideroblastic anaemia?
questions.explanation:
Sideroblastic Anemia

It is a condition characterized by defective heme synthesis in the bone marrow, leading to the accumulation of iron within the mitochondria of red blood cell precursors (sideroblasts).

Causes
  • Congenital causes:  Due to enzyme deficiencies like ALA synthase, ferrochelatase, etc.
  • Acquired causes
  • Vitamin B6 deficiency
  • Drugs like isoniazid and chloramphenicol
  • Lead and alcohol poisoning

Pathogenesis
  • Vitamin B6 is crucial for the proper function of enzymes in heme synthesis.
  • As a cofactor for aminolevulinic acid synthase, it aids in the first step of heme production.
  • Ensuring sufficient vitamin B6 restores enzyme activity, supports heme synthesis, and helps alleviate symptoms of sideroblastic anaemia.

Microscopy

Peripheral Smear: Pappenheimer bodies

  • Multiple basophilic iron aggregates
  • Stain blue with Perl's/ Prussian blue
  • Seen in  sideroblastic anaemia, lead poisoning, or hemochromatosis

 

 

Bone Marrow: Ringed Sideroblasts

  • Blue granules form a full or partial ring
  • Blasts have a nucleus
  • Iron is present in mitochondria in the perinuclear region.
  • Stain blue on Perl's/Prussian blue.
  • Seen with Sideroblastic anemia and Myelodysplastic syndrome.
  • Associated with SF3B1 mutation

 

 

 

Vitamin B1 (Option C), or thiamine, plays a key role in carbohydrate metabolism and nerve function. Its deficiency causes conditions like Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome and Beriberi, but it is not linked to sideroblastic anaemia.

Vitamin B12 (Option A) deficiency causes megaloblastic anaemia and neurological symptoms. It results from poor diet, malabsorption, or lack of intrinsic factors. In sideroblastic anaemia, vitamin B6 is used instead of vitamin B12 because it helps correct the heme synthesis defect, while B12 is not involved in this process.

 

Iron (Option D) deficiency presents with symptoms like pale skin, shortness of breath, dizziness or lightheadedness, brittle nails, headaches, restless legs syndrome, etc. In sideroblastic anaemia, treatment focuses on addressing the underlying cause, as the main issue is impaired heme synthesis. Iron supplementation is generally ineffective and may worsen the condition by increasing iron accumulation in tissues.

questions.text: In iron deficiency anaemia, all of the following are increased except:
questions.explanation:
Iron Study

Interpretation in Iron Deficiency Anemia

Serum Ferritin

Low (< 30 ng/mL)

Serum Iron (Fe)

Low

Serum transferrin saturation

(Option A)

Low

Total Iron Binding Capacity (TIBC) (Option C ruled out)

Increased: TIBC reflects the increased capacity of transferrin to bind iron in response to low iron stores.

Red Cell Distribution Width (RDW)

Increased

Ferritin soluble receptors (sTfR)(Option D ruled out)

Increased

RBC protoporphyrin (Option B ruled out)

Increased

Bone Marrow Aspiration and Iron Staining

Confirmatory test for Iron deficiency anaemia.

The general examination showed pallor, and the systemic examination was unremarkable. Laboratory examination revealed a Hb level of 3 g/dl, a TLC of 1500/microL, and a platelet count of 15,000/microL. A peripheral smear shows macrocytes, and the reticulocyte count is 0.5%. A bone marrow examination revealed fatty streaks and absent megakaryocytes with no immature cells. What is the likely diagnosis?
In a patient of hereditary spherocytosis, which of the following organisms is likely to attack progenitor cells, resulting in aplastic anemia?
questions.explanation: Correct Option C - Parvovirus B19

questions.text: What is your diagnosis with respect to the findings shown in the peripheral smear:
questions.explanation:
Bone Marrow

Biochemical Tests
  • Hypercellular bone marrow
  • Erythroid Hyperplasia
  • Sieve-like chromatin
  • Hypersegmented neutrophils
  • Reversal of myeloid: erythroid ratio 1:1 or less (Normal: 3:1)
  • Nuclear-cytoplasmic asynchrony.
  • Serum bilirubin: Increases
  • Serum LDH: Increases
  • Vitamin B12: Decreases
  • Folic acid: Decreases
  • Anti-intrinsic factor (IF) antibody: Present (Pernicious anaemia)
  • Methylmalonyl CoA: Increases
  • Homocysteine: Increases
  • Schilling Test: Assess the cause of B12 deficiency.

Folic Acid Deficiency 

Vitamin B12 Deficiency 
  • Site of absorption - Jejunum.
  • Seen in: Alcoholics, pregnancy.
  • Causes neural tube defects.
  • Neurological symptoms are not seen.
  • Normal methylmalonic acid.
  • High homocysteine.
  • FIGLU test positive.
  • Site of absorption - Ileum.
  • Seen in: Vegetarians, pregnancy, Diphyllobothrium latum infection.
  • Neurological manifestation: Subacute combined degeneration.
  • High methylmalonic acid.
  • High homocysteine.

questions.text: Identify the cells marked in the given image:
Which of the following is not true about stem cells?

options.label: C
options.text: They can divide without any regulatory stimulus

questions.correct_answer: C. They can divide without any regulatory stimulus

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency?

options.label: C
options.text: Cells do not lyse in a hypotonic solution

questions.explanation:
Abnormality

Condition

Reason

Bite cells

G6PD deficiency
  • Oxidative stress leads to cross-linking of sulfhydryl groups in haemoglobin → Denaturation of haemoglobin → Heinz bodies.
  • RBCs with Heinz bodies pass through the spleen → Splenic macrophages try to pluck these Heinz bodies → Membrane loss → Bite cells.

Target cells

Thalassemia
  • ↓ Haemoglobin content in RBCs → ↓ RBC volume → Surface area relatively unchanged → ↑ Surface area to volume ratio→ Altered lipid composition → ↑ Formation of membrane protrusions→ ↑ Membrane instability → ↓ Hemoglobin accumulation in certain membrane areas → Central area with haemoglobin, clear zone, outer ring.
  • Uneven distribution of haemoglobin and lipids → Characteristic "bull's-eye" appearance of Target cells

Sickle-shaped RBC

Sickle Cell Anemia

Abnormal Hemoglobin (HbS) → HbS molecules polymerize under low oxygen → RBCs become rigid and assume a sickle shape.

 

 

Spherocytes

Hereditary Spherocytosis

Genetic defect in RBC membrane protein(spectrin) ⟶ Loss of membrane surface area ⟶ RBCs become spherical.

questions.text: A 9-month-old boy presents with progressive pallor and abdominal distention. On investigations, hepatosplenomegaly and malar eminence are seen, and his peripheral blood smear is shown below. He has a low Hb; the Mentzer index is less than 13. What diagnosis would this signify for this patient?
questions.explanation:
Thalassemia Major (β-Thalassemia Major)

Features

Description

Definition

A severe form of β-thalassemia caused by homozygous or compound heterozygous mutations in the β-globin gene (HBB) on chromosome 11, leading to absent or markedly reduced β-globin chain production.

Genetics

Autosomal recessive disorder, caused by mutations in the β-globin gene leading to defective hemoglobin synthesis.

Pathophysiology

Reduced or absent β-globin chains lead to excess α-globin chains, which form unstable precipitates, causing ineffective erythropoiesis, hemolysis, and severe anaemia.

Clinical Features

Symptoms appear around 6 months of age (as fetal haemoglobin declines); severe anaemia, growth retardation, hepatosplenomegaly, skeletal deformities (crew-cut appearance on skull X-ray, frontal bossing), jaundice, and delayed puberty.

Hematological Findings
  • Peripheral smear: Microcytic hypochromic anaemia, target cells, anisopoikilocytosis, nucleated RBCs.
  • Bone marrow: Erythroid hyperplasia with expansion of marrow cavities.

Hemoglobin Electrophoresis

Absent or very low HbA, markedly increased HbF (>90%), variable HbA2.

Complications
  • Iron overload (due to repeated transfusions leading to secondary hemochromatosis)
  • Cardiac failure (due to iron deposition)
  • Endocrinopathies (diabetes, hypothyroidism, hypogonadism)
  • Osteopenia/osteoporosis
  • Increased infection risk (especially from Yersinia and viral infections).

Diagnosis

Blood tests (CBC, peripheral smear), Hb electrophoresis/HPLC, Serum ferritin (for iron overload), Genetic testing (HBB gene mutations), Prenatal diagnosis (chorionic villus sampling or amniocentesis).

Treatment

Regular blood transfusions, iron chelation therapy (deferoxamine, deferasirox, deferiprone), splenectomy (in refractory cases), and hematopoietic stem cell transplantation (HSCT) (only curative option).

Prevention

Carrier screening, genetic counselling, prenatal diagnosis, preimplantation genetic diagnosis (PGD) in high-risk couples.

Feature

 

Iron Deficiency Anemia

Beta Thalassemia Minor

 

Type

Microcytic hypochromic anemia

Microcytic hypochromic anemia

RBC

Less

More

MCV

Normal to low

Low

RDW(size variance)

More

Normal

Mentzer index: MCV/RBC

>13

<13

Reticulocyte count

Low

Normal to slightly increased

HbA2 - confirmatory test

<3.5%

>3.5%

questions.text: Investigations of a patient being evaluated for leukaemia revealed a WBC count of 450,000/μL, with eosinophilia and basophilia. What is the likely diagnosis in this case?
questions.explanation:
Chronic Myeloid Leukemia (CML)

Category

Description

Genetics

Philadelphia chromosome t(9;22)

Origin

Myeloid lineage

Etiopathogenesis

BCR-ABL fusion gene from t(9;22) increases tyrosine kinase activity, leading to uncontrolled myeloid proliferation. Radiation exposure is a risk factor.

Clinical Features
  • Affects adults.
  • Presents with splenomegaly, fatigue, weight loss, night sweats, and abdominal discomfort.
  • It can progress to blast crisis, resembling acute leukaemia.

Diagnosis
  • Bone marrow aspirate to confirm.
  • FISH detects the BCR-ABL fusion gene.

Bone Marrow aspirate findings.
  • Presence of scattered macrophages with abundant wrinkled, green-blue cytoplasm, called sea-blue histiocytes or pseudo-Gaucher cells.
  • The marrow is markedly hypercellular due to massively increased numbers of maturing granulocytic precursors (elevated eosinophils and basophils)
  • Increased megakaryocytes, commonly with small, dysplastic forms called dwarf megakaryocytes.
  • Normal or slightly decreased erythroid progenitors (increased myeloid: erythroid ratio).
  • Increased deposition of reticulin fibres.

Management

Tyrosine kinase inhibitors (TKIs) like Imatinib.

Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia (ALL) (Option A):

  • Lymphoblasts in bone marrow >=20%
  • Cytoplasmic vacuolations
  • They contain fat (Oil Red O Positive)
  • Hand mirror-shaped cells

Acute Myeloid Leukemia (AML) (Option D):

  • Blasts ≥ 20%
  • Myeloblasts with AuerRods

Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia (CLL) (Option C):

  • Smudge cells (or parachute/basket cell): Due to the fragility of lymphocytes during slide preparation
  • Convent girl appearance: Lot of homogenous, small, mature-like, round lymphocytes with scant cytoplasm

Chronic Myeloid Leukemia (CML):

  • Leukocytosis
  • Cell Types: Neutrophils( multilobed nucleus), metamyelocytes (indented nucleus), myelocytes (D-shaped nucleus), and eosinophils (orange cells)
  • College girl/garden party appearance: Due to the variety of cell appearances
  • Shift to the Left: Presence of immature cell types, mainly immature neutrophils, in the blood.

The peripheral smear shows microcytic hypochromic red blood cells. What is the most likely diagnosis?

Iron Study

Interpretation in Iron Deficiency Anemia

Serum Ferritin

Low (< 30 ng/mL) indicates depleted iron stores.

Serum Iron (Fe)

Low levels are seen in iron deficiency anaemia.

Total Iron Binding Capacity (TIBC)

Increased TIBC reflects the increased capacity of transferrin to bind iron in response to low iron stores.

Red Cell Distribution Width (RDW)

Increased RDW is often seen in iron deficiency anaemia

Bone Marrow Aspiration and Iron Staining

Confirmatory test

Microcytic Anaemia

Normocytic Anaemia

Macrocytic Anaemia

questions.text: Match the following cell types with their associated malignancy: Cell Type Associated Malignancy 1. Popcorn cell a. Acute promyelocytic leukemia 2. Faggot cell b. Lymphocyte-predominant Hodgkin’s lymphoma 3. Cerebriform nuclei c. Burkitt lymphoma 4. Starry sky appearance d. Sezary syndrome
questions.explanation:
Cell Type

Associated Malignancy

Popcorn cell

Lymphocyte-predominant Hodgkin’s lymphoma

Faggot cell

Acute promyelocytic leukemia

Cerebriform nuclei

Sezary syndrome

Starry sky appearance

Burkitt lymphoma

Popcorn cells
  • Cells with multiple infolded nuclear membranes, small nucleoli, fine chromatin, and abundant pale cytoplasm.
  • Seen in Nodular lymphocyte-Predominant Hodgkin lymphoma.

AML-M3

Acute promyelocytic leukemia
  • t(15:17) - PML-RAR𝛼 fusion
  • Blocks promyelocyte → myelocyte transformation
  • Bone marrow: Auer rods form criss-cross called faggot cell
  • Can cause DIC
  • PAS+

questions.text: A patient presents with fever, night sweats, and weight loss for 2 months. On examination, non-tender rubbery nodes are palpable in the supraclavicular and inguinal regions on both sides. A peripheral smear shows the presence of binucleated cells. Which of the following markers will be seen in this condition? CD15 CD30 CD19 CD3
questions.explanation:
Feature

Hodgkin Lymphoma (HL)

Non-Hodgkin Lymphoma (NHL)

Age of presentation

Bimodal distribution peaks in young adults (15-35 years) and older adults (over 55).

It is more common in older adults but can occur at any age.

Localisation

More often localised to a single axial group of nodes (cervical, mediastinal, para-aortic)

More frequent involvement of multiple peripheral nodes.

Pattern of Spread

Orderly spread by contiguity.

Non Contiguous spread

Involvement of Mesenteric Nodes and Waldeyer Ring

Mesenteric nodes and Waldeyer ring are rarely involved.

Waldeyer ring and mesenteric nodes are commonly involved.

Extranodal Presentation

Extranodal presentation is rare.

Extranodal presentation is common.

questions.text: Which of the following for Sickle cell anaemia is correct?

options.label: A
options.text: Low mechanical fragility, high osmotic fragility

options.label: B
options.text: High mechanical fragility, high osmotic fragility

options.label: C
options.text: Low mechanical fragility, low osmotic fragility

options.label: D
options.text: High mechanical fragility, low osmotic fragility

questions.correct_answer: D. High mechanical fragility, low osmotic fragility

questions.text: Which of the following is a feature of hemolytic anaemia?

A child presents with intermittent jaundice and splenomegaly. There is a history of similar complaints in the elder brother. A peripheral smear shows the following findings. Which of the following is the most appropriate diagnostic test for this condition?
questions.correct_answer: A. Osmotic fragility test - Hereditary spherocytosis
questions.explanation:
Mutations of ankyrin, band 3, spectrin, or band 4.2

↓

Unstable RBC membrane with membrane loss

↓

The surface: volume ratio is reduced

↓

RBC takes up the shape of a sphere to compensate

↓

Spherical RBCs are trapped in splenic sinusoids due to large size

↓

Extravascular hemolysis

questions.text: Hepcidin inhibits iron transfer from the enterocyte to the plasma by binding to:
questions.explanation: Correct Option A - F

questions.text: Choose the correct option regarding the storage temperature of blood components.
questions.explanation: Correct Option B - RBC = 2-6ºC, Platelet = 20-24ºC, FFP = -18ºC

questions.text: What is correct regarding transfusion of the blood received from the blood bank?

options.label: A
options.text: It should be started within 4 hours of receiving it from the blood bank

options.label: B
options.text: It should be completed within 4 hours of receiving it from the blood bank

options.label: C
options.text: No such time restraint and can be done anytime

options.label: D
options.text: It should be completed within 6 hours of receiving it from the blood bank

questions.correct_answer: B. It should be completed within 4 hours of receiving it from the blood bank
questions.explanation: Correct Option B - It should be completed within 4 hours of receiving it from the blood bank

questions.text: In iron deficiency anemia, all of the following are reduced , except :
questions.explanation:
Correct Option A - Total iron binding capacity:

Iron Deficiency Anemia
Serum iron ↓
Total iron binding capacity ↑
Transferrin saturation ↓
Serum ferritin ↓
Soluble transferrin receptor ↑
Serum RBC protoporphyrin ↑

Iron Deficiency Anemia
Serum iron ↓
Total iron binding capacity ↑
Transferrin saturation ↓
Serum ferritin ↓
Soluble transferrin receptor ↑
Serum RBC protoporphyrin ↑

questions.text: CD-59 is involved in:
questions.explanation: Correct Option A - Paroxysmal Nocturnal Hemoglobinu

questions.text: What is the diagnosis for an individual whose serum alkaline phosphatase is normal, PTH is normal, and vitamin D3 is normal with elevated serum calcium ?

Correct Option C - Multiple M

Primary Hyperparathyroidism ↑/N ↑ Low phosphate
Secondary Hyperparathyroidism ↑ ↓/N CKD
Tertiary Hyperparathyroidism ↑ ↑ High phosphate + CKD
Vitamin D deficiency ↑/N ↓/N  
Vitamin D excess ↓ ↑  
Pseudohypoparathyroidism ↑ ↓ High phosphate

questions.text: A 40-year-old male presented to OPD with complaints of itching during baths . His hemoglobin was 20%, his platelet count was 89000/mL, and his WBC count was 30,000/mL. What is the most likely diagnosis ?
questions.explanation: Correct Option C - Polycythemia V

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding the use of the instrument given in the image below?

options.label: C
options.text: Procedure cannot be done in both lateral and prone positions

options.label: D
options.text: Diagnosing an infiltrate or granulomatous disease

questions.explanation:
Correct Option A - Contraindicated if coagulopathy:

References:

  • ↳ A bone marrow biopsy can be performed with the patient in either a lateral or prone position.
  • ↳ The choice of position depends on the preference of the physician and patient comfort.
  • ↳ Option D - Diagnosing an infiltrate or granulomatous disease:
  • ↳ Option D - Diagnosing an infiltrate or granulomatous disease:
  • ↳ A bone marrow biopsy is a diagnostic procedure used to evaluate various conditions, including hematologic disorders, metastatic cancer, infections, and bone marrow failure syndromes. While an infiltrate or granulomatous disease may be detected through a bone marrow biopsy, it is not specific to this procedure alone.
  • ↳ A bone marrow biopsy is a diagnostic procedure used to evaluate various conditions, including hematologic disorders, metastatic cancer, infections, and bone marrow failure syndromes.
  • ↳ While an infiltrate or granulomatous disease may be detected through a bone marrow biopsy, it is not specific to this procedure alone.

questions.text: Which transporter is required for the transport of iron into the enterocyte?
questions.explanation: Correct Option B - Divalent

questions.text: Which of the following are features of iron deficiency anaemia?

questions.text: Which of the following is not routinely screened before conducting a blood transfusion?
questions.explanation: Correct Option A - Hepatitis A

questions.text: A child visited the hospital with her mother with complaints of severe fatigue, lethargy, pallor, and irritation. She has a known case of iron deficiency anemia and is on oral iron supplements. On reviewing the child, the physician in charge plans to start IV iron supplementation. What is the next best test to be done in assessing this child?
questions.explanation: Correct Option C - Serum   Iron deficiency anemia Anemia of chronic disease Sideroblastic anemia Serum iron ↓ ↓ ↑ Transferrin saturation ↓ ↓ ↑ Ferritin ↓ ↑ ↑ Total iron binding capacity ↑ ↓ ↓

questions.text: Which of the following stains is used for the detection of hemosiderin deposits?
questions.explanation: Correct Option D - Perls Prussian Blu

questions.text: In which of the following conditions is macrocytic anemia seen?
questions.explanation: Correct Option D - Liv
